column1: Murzuq (Arabic: مرزق‎ Murzuq) is one of the districts of Libya.  It is in the south of the country.  Its capital is Murzuk. The city was occupied by the Ottoman Empire in 1578 and served as the capital of Fezzan off and on until the Ottomans ceded Libya to Italy in 1912.  It was not occupied by the Italians until 1914.

column2: Murzuq borders the Bourkou-Ennedi-Tibesti Region of Chad
column3: and to the southwest it borders the Agadez Department of Niger. The border crossing to Niger is at Tumu. Domestically
column4: it borders Ghat in the west

column1: Libya has mostly a flat undulating plain and occasional plateau
column2: with an average elevation of around 423 m (1
column3: 388 ft). Around 91 per cent of the land is covered by desert
column4: with only 8.8 per cent agricultural land (with only 1% arable lands) and 0.1 per cent of forests. The major resources are petroleum
column5: gypsum and natural gas. Along the coastal regions
column6: the climate is Mediterranean in coastal areas
column7: while it is desert climate in all other parts. Dust storms lasting four to eight days is pretty common during Spring. Triplotania is the northwest region
column8: while it is Cyrenacia in the east and Fezzen in southwest. Fezzen is mostly full of deserts. The region receives an annual rainfall of 2.5 in (64 mm). There are no perennial rivers in the region
column9: but the region is abundant with groundwater aquifers.

column1: The border between Murzuq and Jufra districts was modified after 2007 administrative reorganization of Libyan Districts. Among the towns in Murzuq district are Qatrun
column6: and Tajarhi. Libya became independent in 1951 from the colonial empire and generally known for its oil rich resources. All the powers rested centrally with the President Gaddafi for 42 years till the 2011 armed rebellion which topple him. As per the constitution
column7: Libya is the most decentralized Arab nation
column8: but practically all powers are vested on central government on account of control over the oil revenues. Local governmental institutions manage the administration of education
column10: and communities. As a part of decentralization in 2012
column11: the country is administratively split into 13 regions from the original 25 municipalities
column14: the chief of the state is a Chairman of Presidential Council
column15: while the Prime Minister is the head of the state. The House of Representatives is an elected body that is elected on universal suffrage and popular vote. As of 2016
column16: there were 22 administrative divisions in the country in the form of districts.
